conclusion: Use the first law of thermodynamics to determine heat transfer.
Internal energy change for an ideal gas depends only on temperature.
Assume process A to B is isochoric and B to C is isobaric.
Volume remains constant from A to B.
Temperature at A is 300 K.
No work is done from A to B since volume is constant.
Change in internal energy from A to B is nCvΔT.
Pressure remains constant from B to C.
Volume changes from 1x10^-3 m^3 to 3x10^-3 m^3 from B to C.
Work done from B to C is 200 J.
Calculate temperature at state B using ideal gas law.
nR = 100 J/K from state A conditions.
Temperature at B is 1000 K.
Calculate change in internal energy for B to C.
nR = 100 J/K from state B conditions.
Temperature at C is 300 K.
Change in temperature from B to C is -700 K.
ΔU_BC = nCv(-700 K).
Total heat transfer Q = ΔU_AB + ΔU_BC.
Q = ΔU_BC since ΔU_AB = 0.
Exact numerical value of Q cannot be determined without nCv.
Final answer: Heat transfer depends on n and Cv, which are not provided.
